title: "Universal graph" dashboard

"Universal graph" dashboard
If the tabular representation of data is insufficient for analytical actions and decision-making, graphical tools should be used to enhance data visualization by integrating the "Universal graph" analytical dashboard into the user interface.
Highcharts allow not only to visualize data in an interactive format, but also to graphically output it as an image or a PDF document.
The creation of charts and diagrams, their visualization, and the interactivity of the dialogue (such as animation, element highlighting, tooltips, etc.) are made possible by integrating the Highcharts software library into the GreenData platform.
For example, the demonstration of quarterly shipment tonnage across three cities can be presented as follows:
Graphs and charts are configured and placed on screen forms (
dashboard
).
To create or access an existing dashboard, the user needs to open the main menu of the System and sequentially select the following menu items:
Reports → Dashboards
.
A new dashboard is created by clicking the
button and then specifying the name and saving the new dashboard.
The user needs to drag and drop (Drag&Drop) the "Universal graph" analytical panel in the dashboard edit mode (find more about
dashboard settings
) from the "Panels based on a source" section into the profile working area.
The "Universal graph" analytical panel can only be dragged into the "Row" space container, available under the "Groupings" tab.
It is highly recommended to use an attribute group or a tab group as the grouping container.
Pre-configuration
To configure the parameters of the
"Universal graph"
analytical panel, a data source must be prepared within the used dashboard. This source should be formed
based on an algorithm
that returns a diagram.
This algorithm transmits data for chart/diagram construction and directly configures the chart/diagram display in the dashboard profile.
Chart implementation scheme.
Data source formation
To form a data source, the user needs to switch to edit mode in the dashboard, navigate to the source management window, and add a source based on an algorithm.
When creating a source, its name and
the algorithm forming the source
are specified. The algorithm can be selected from pre-prepared algorithms, created using the "Add" action, or edited during the source creation process using the "Edit" action.
Algorithm
The GreenData platform supports the full range of Highcharts charts.
Writing the algorithm code
can be done manually, but a more productive way will be the implementation of the previously configured chart templates.
A ready-made algorithm template can be inserted by selecting a function from the
"Charts"
tab of the algorithm editor:
newDonutChart
- Donut Chart;
newPyramidChart
- Pyramid Chart;
newFunnelChart
- Funnel Chart;
newChart
- Combined Chart;
newPieChart
- Pie Chart;
newLineChart
- Linear Chart;
newSplineChart
- Spline Diagram;
newColumnChart
- Column Chart;
newBarChart
- Bar Comparison Cjart;
newAreaChart
- Area Diagram.
The template code is functional but requires manual adjustment to fit the specific task conditions.
For more information about the functions and methods used to create charts, see the article
"Universal chart configuration"
.
The key objects of the chart, along with their parameters and components configured using the algorithm code, are:
1.
Chart
.
Including:
title;
sub title;
horizontal axis (name and scale);
vertical axis (name and scale).
2.
Legend
.
Including:
permission (for use);
horizontal alignment;
vertical alignment;
location (horizontal or vertical).
3.
Series
(data set).
Data entry (final value or value and signature pair).
Depending on the chart, the set of elements available for customization will be different.
For example, when programmatically constructing a pie chart, axes and their signatures will not be displayed.
Chart’s logical limitations can be managed, if necessary, by using a combined chart, which can include various types of diagrams.
Configuration parameters
If a
configured source
based on an
algorithm
is available, the user can proceed with configuring the
added
"Universal graph" analytical panel in the dashboard workspace. To do this, click the
button.
As a result, a modal window will open, where the configuration parameters are located across three tabs.
Main settings
The "Base" tab defines the primary parameters of the analytical panel:
Setting
Purpose
Data source
Selecting a
configured data source
.
Table name
Entering a name for the universal chart.
The other functionality of the chart is determined by its type and a set of components that must be returned by the
algorithm
.
Decryption
This tab configures the relation between two or more analytical panels. In other words, this setting allows real-time changes to the data display of one analytical panel based on the selected value of another analytical panel.
For more details on decryption settings, refer to "
Data Drill Down (Decryption)
".
Result
After configuring a chart, the system will display it in the dashboard profile.
All charts are scripting components of the JavaScript language. Their contents can be cached by the browser. Therefore, if the chart has not been updated despite the changes made by the business analyst, the page needs to refreshed by F5 key.
Examples of generating various static charts (graphs) can be found below.
Examples of highcharts
We won’t be analyzing separate technical actions for creating, filling and formatting chart elements, since the result will be obtained only in a combination of actions. Therefore, by using a series of examples, we will take a closer look at the key actions of algorithms that generate graphs and diagrams.
Line chart
Creation of a line chart includes its axes and the output of series names. The preferred scale value is calculated automatically.
Interactive options involve the appearance of an explanatory footnote and shaded inactive elements.
Example of a line graph algorithm created with
newLineChart
function.
def
chart :
= newLineChart( )
chart.
title :
=
"Line chart"
chart.
subTitle :
=
"Based on trigonometric expressions"
chart.yAxis.
title :
=
"Y-axis value"
def
s1 :
= newChartSerie( )
s1.
name :
=
"Expression with sine"
def
s2 :
= newChartSerie( )
s2.
name :
=
"Combination of functions"
s2.
color :
=
"#FF0000"
for
(
def
i:
=
1
; i<
20
;
i:
=i+
1
){
s1.values.add(round(
10
*Math.sin(i/
3
),
0
))
s2.values.add(round(
6
*Math.sin(i*
2
)*Math.cos(i/
2
),
2
))
}
chart.series.add(s1)
chart.series.add(s2)
chart
groovy
Copied!
By default, charts provide interactive display of content in the browser window.
Getting a result in the form of a document or a picture is possible using a chart context menu button
located in the upper right corner of the graph area.
This menu allows selecting the preferred way for downloading the graph snapshot in PNG, JPEG, SVG formats, as well as a PDF document format.
Bar chart
It can be used to display data of one series (single-color graph) and for comparative analysis of data of several series (see below). It is strongly recommended to use a legend when analyzing data from several series.
When you move your mouse over the columns, an explanatory footnote will appear with the columns of inactive series highlighted.
Example of a bar chart algorithm created with
newColumnChart
function.
def
chart :
= newColumnChart()
chart.
title :
=
"Bar chart"
chart.
subTitle :
=
"Actual volume of deliveries in tons"
chart.xAxis.
title :
=
"Annual deliveries in tons"
chart.yAxis.
title :
=
""
def
legend :
= newChartLegendParams(
true
,
"right"
,
"middle"
,
"vertical"
)
chart.
legend :
= legend
for
(
def
k:
=
1
; k<
5
;
k:
=k+
1
){
chart.xAxis.categories.add(
"Per "
+k+
" quarter"
)
}
def
serie :
= newColumnChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Chicago"
serie.
color :
=
"#FF0000"
serie.values.add(
18
)
serie.values.add(
27
)
serie.values.add(
32
)
serie.values.add(
16
)
chart.series.add(serie)
serie :
= newColumnChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Dallas"
serie.values.add(
11
)
serie.values.add(
20
)
serie.values.add(
35
)
serie.values.add(
27
)
chart.series.add(serie)
serie :
= newColumnChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Houston"
serie.values.add(
3
)
serie.values.add(
7
)
serie.values.add(
21
)
serie.values.add(
39
)
chart.series.add(serie)
chart
groovy
Copied!
Pie chart
Used for visualizing of data and uniform indicators distributed across segments.
The diagram often requires to have a corporate palette which is cyclically assigned by a color palette.
When moving your mouse over the segment, an explanatory footnote will appear and inactive elements will be shadowed.
Example of a pie chart algorithm created with
newPieChart
function.
def
chart :
= newPieChart()
chart.
title :
=
"Pie chart"
chart.
subTitle :
=
"Total delivery by city"
setChartColors(chart,
'#148E5F'
,
'#00FF00'
,
'#66FF66'
,
'#99FF99'
,
'#CCFFCC'
)
def
serie :
= newPieChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Delivery"
serie.values.add(
19
,
"Washington"
)
serie.values.add(
9
,
"New York"
)
serie.values.add(
7.6
,
"Houston"
)
serie.values.add(
5
,
"Dallas"
)
serie.values.add(
3
,
"Chicago"
)
chart.series.add(serie)
chart
groovy
Copied!
Donut Chart
A donut chart is a variation of a pie chart with a free space in the center.
When moving your mouse over the segment, an explanatory footnote will appear and inactive elements will be shadowed.
Example of a donut chart algorithm created with
newDonutChart
function.
def
chart :
= newPieChart()
chart.
title :
=
"Donut chart"
chart.
subTitle :
=
"Total delivery by region"
setChartColors(chart,
'#148E5F'
,
'#00FF00'
,
'#66FF66'
,
'#99FF99'
,
'#CCFFCC'
)
def
serie :
= newChartSerie()
serie.
innerSize :
=
"80%"
serie.
name :
=
"Delivery"
serie.values.add(
19
,
"Washington"
)
serie.values.add(
9
,
"New York"
)
serie.values.add(
7.6
,
"Dallas"
)
serie.values.add(
5
,
"Houston"
)
serie.values.add(
3
,
"Chicago"
)
chart.series.add(serie)
chart
groovy
Copied!
The "innerSize" parameter is set in %. For the correct representation of the chart, the user needs to specify the value of <100%.
Funnel chart
Funnel charts help visualize a process consisting of stages, where elements sequentially transition from one stage to another.
This chart type is commonly used to represent sales process stages and display the amount of potential revenue for each stage.
When moving your mouse over levels of the funnel, an explanatory footnote will appear and inactive elements will be shadowed.
Example of a funnel chart algorithm created with
newFunnelChart
function.
def
chart :
= newFunnelChart()
chart.
title :
=
"Funnel chart"
chart.
subTitle :
=
"Sales funnel for an ad, number of people"
setChartColors(chart,
'#D8BFD8'
,
'#BA55D3'
,
'#8A2BE2'
,
'#9400D3'
,
'#800080'
,
'#4B0082'
)
def
serie :
= newChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Sales funnel"
serie.values.add(
9056
,
"Ad display"
)
serie.values.add(
3483
,
"Website visits"
)
serie.values.add(
2004
,
"Products added to cart"
)
serie.values.add(
467
,
"Checkout"
)
serie.values.add(
454
,
"Payment"
)
serie.values.add(
189
,
"Repeat purchase"
)
chart.series.add(serie)
def
plotOpt :
= newChartPlotOptions()
plotOpt.
width :
=
"70%"
plotOpt.
height :
=
"100%"
plotOpt.
neckWidth :
=
"20%"
plotOpt.
neckHeight :
=
"30%"
chart.
plotOptions :
= plotOpt
chart
groovy
Copied!
Pyramid chart
This chart type uses a triangular diagram to visually represent hierarchies. The triangle is divided into sections illustrating vertically descending and wide-narrow structures and processes.
When moving your mouse over levels of the pyramid, an explanatory footnote will appear and inactive elements will be shadowed.
Example of a pyramid chart algorithm created with
newPyramidChart
function.
def
chart :
= newPyramidChart()
chart.
title :
=
"Pyramid chart"
chart.
subTitle :
=
"Distribution of land by continents"
setChartColors(chart,
'#228B22'
,
'#FF8C00'
,
'#FFFF00'
,
'#E9967A'
,
'#E0FFFF'
,
'#00CED1'
)
def
serie :
= newChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Distribution of land by continents, %"
serie.values.add(
37
,
"Eurasia"
)
serie.values.add(
20
,
"Africa"
)
serie.values.add(
16
,
"North America"
)
serie.values.add(
12
,
"South America"
)
serie.values.add(
9
,
"Antarctica"
)
serie.values.add(
6
,
"Australia and Oceania"
)
chart.series.add(serie)
def
plotOpt :
= newChartPlotOptions()
plotOpt.
width :
=
'60%'
plotOpt.
height :
=
'100%'
chart.
plotOptions :
= plotOpt
chart
groovy
Copied!
Combination chart
In complicated cases, when several different charts need to be combined in the chart area, we usually use a combination chart. By using such a container, you can sequentially add series (datasets) of various formats (as shown below).
Other options for creating charts are different combinations of the actions given in the examples above.
Example of a combination chart algorithm created with
newChart
function:
def
chart :
= newChart()
chart.
title :
=
"Combination chart"
chart.
subTitle :
=
"Transportation on working days and weekends"
chart.yAxis.
title:
=
""
chart.xAxis.categories.add(
"January"
)
chart.xAxis.categories.add(
"February"
)
chart.xAxis.categories.add(
"March"
)
chart.xAxis.categories.add(
"April"
)
def
serie :
= newPieChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Total consumption"
serie.values.add(
221
,
"Total on working days"
)
serie.values.add(
157
,
"Total on weekends"
)
chart.series.add(serie)
serie :
= newColumnChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Working days"
serie.
color :
=
"#77FF77"
serie.values.add(
50
)
serie.values.add(
78
)
serie.values.add(
8
)
serie.values.add(
85
)
chart.series.add(serie)
serie :
= newColumnChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Weekends"
serie.
color :
=
"#777777"
serie.values.add(
20
)
serie.values.add(
60
)
serie.values.add(
12
)
serie.values.add(
65
)
chart.series.add(serie)
serie :
= newSplineChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Averaged"
serie.
color :
=
"#FFB800"
serie.values.add(
35
)
serie.values.add(
69
)
serie.values.add(
10
)
serie.values.add(
75
)
chart.series.add(serie)
chart
groovy
Copied!
